item.name: 1960: The Making of the President
item.comment:
Have played this twice now and I think I've had my fill. To be honest, I didn't enjoy playing 1960 much. I feel a little guilty rating it on that criteria, but since I do it with other games, I should here, too. There's a couple reasons I hesitate and even rated 1960 higher at first: first, I think it's one of those games where the first couples times are pretty much bound to be a bit of a struggle, where you spend the game trying to get the flow rather than focusing more on strategy and enjoyment; second, it's incredibly well-done and deserves to be recognized for being a great game of its type, even if it isn't -my- type of game. That all said and told, though, it ends up being an somewhat unenjoyable affair for me, because I don't like the give-and-take this game affords.
Z-man did a fantastic presentation job with this game. Everything looks just right; they managed to make the board interesting despite the fact that it's largely just a map of the U.S. (they even put a fake coffee mug ring on it to make it look like some sort of political war-room map). The bits and cards are all high-quality, the little factoids on the cards are interesting. A+ design here.
And the mechanics are really quite interesting and amazing. The draw bag has that "mysterious game piece of power" feel to it, like the cube tower from Shogun or the Sauron die in Lord of the Rings. You learn to respect and fear it. The game -feels- thematically correct; there's never enough time to do everything, and it's a brutal tug-of-war for the states with the most electoral clout. There's some mechanics that didn't click as well with me--like the momentum markers--but at least part of that is still my only vague grasp of how to play the game well.
Despite all this, I just get the feeling it's not really a game I'll ever really enjoy. It's essentially an incredibly rough war/area-control game where you fight claw and nail for every inch of progress. I find games where everything you've done on your turn can be (and often is) flatly reversed by the opponent on their following turn (this was my problem with Coloretto Amazonas). It's thematically appropriate here, but it's frustrating for me to spend two or three turns trading cubes on New York. Maybe that would happen a bit less if I were more experienced--maybe I'd learn to focus attention on other things where my opponent wouldn't thwart me as much, I don't know--but as it was I felt like I barely kept the status quo for most of the game.
Anyhow, short version: this game is amazingly designed and presented and you should give it at least a shot. But, personally, it's not my type of game.

item.name: 6 Nimmt!
item.comment: I'll save my full comments for Slide 5, since that's the version I own, but I'll just quickly say that I prefer the snazzy-and-nonsensical bull-head motif of 6 Nimmt! to the blander skiing theme for Slide 5. Plus, the large bull-head in the middle of the cards makes it MUCH easier to tell which way is right-side up.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.wishlistcomment: Often out of stock, but currently www.thoughthammer.com has copies in stock. Would LOVE this!!!

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: Fantastic game of investment, temporary alliances, and figuring out people's likely moves so you can profit from them.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
Age of Exploration
item.comment: What an awful exercise in tedium. Monotonous "game" that is more simulation than play.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Why is this so enjoyable? No idea. But it -is-. At its base, its mechanics are similar to Caylus (send your workers to certain squares to get certain resources to earn points at the end of the game), but it avoids many of the things about Caylus that I find unenjoyable.
The card decks and semi-random distribution of when actions will be available give a nice sense of randomness without making the game entirely luck-based; basically, you will have a random hand at the beginning that will help guide your strategy, and you will know when most actions will be available, give or take a round or two (but, oh, that give or take can cause so much trouble!).
The scoring rewards having some amount of balance and not totally over-specializing in one section of the game; you need to get at least one of most things to score competitively.
Somehow, despite the many decisions to be made, Agricola doesn't inspire the stiflingly bad analysis paralysis that Caylus seems to carry like a virus. This is probably because you get the resources for a worker as soon as that worker is played, so you don't have to keep reviewing what you WILL be getting and WHEN to make sure you can do action X at the right time.
I haven't played it enough to decide whether its rating will bump up, but right now it's very enjoyable and something I am looking forward to playing again.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: While a couple of the resources are close in color, it's one of those games where this isn't a terribly big deal, and everything's always in the open, so you can just ask other people around the table which is which if needbe. All resource symbols on hidden cards also have a drawing of the resource so being able to distinguish the color is unnecessary.
item.conditiontext:
Edition: Z-man First Edition Language: English Condition: I recounted everything in the box, and found that there is 1 Clay token missing, and 1 extra Grain token. I assume it came in this condition and I just never noticed; this shouldn't have any effect on play. About 10-12 of the original scoring sheets are left on the pad.
The game is in very, very good condition, only been played 10 times-ish, with no noticeable card or piece wear (haven't had any of the problems with flaking paint that I can see).
Box shows slight wear, mostly on blunted corners and a few little dings on the front cover. Also a mild discolored streak on a small portion of the front cover.
[b]Sweeteners[/b]
[thing=37235][/thing] Edition: Z-man First Edition Language: English Condition: Complete, played once or twice.
[b]Mayday Animeeples Set[/b] Never opened.

item.name: Agricola: Through the Seasons
item.comment: Finally got this to hit the table in a 4-player game of Agricola. It's cute, and I found it an enjoyable addition to the experience by shaking things up a bit. I definitely appreciated the sometimes-there Family Growth space, which gave more people the opportunity to get bigger families without room. Also, the tension of occasionally having Winter occur right before a harvest--meaning that getting that piled up Fishing food may not be possible that round--occasionally made things a bit more desperate on the family-feeding front. It did add a bit more upkeep and fiddliness, so I don't think it'll break out too often, but it's not a bad little addition to the game.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: 4/6/10: A little light, but pleasant and interesting. I tend to only play with large groups, because few games accommodate 5-6 well, and Alhambra does a nice job without going on for terribly long. So that has probably skewed my experience toward feeling the game can be a bit random, with not a lot of tactics other than making your wall. And, on that note, I feel after a few plays like the big-wall play is overpoweringly good, almost too required for your strategy to work out well. But given my low number of plays, that could just be wild theorizing. I like the "exact money=extra turn" system, that adds a nice level of calculation and risk-taking without which the game would be quite bland.

item.name: Alhambra: The Dice Game
item.comment:
Euro Yahtzee! I know this game seems to be generally frowned upon by most of the gamer-gamers I know, but I think it's a decent manipulation of the base Yahtzee "Roll three times and try to get as many of X as possible" mechanic to inject more direct competition and player interaction. There is obviously a HUGE luck component, and sometimes there aren't many meaningful decisions to be made when the dice are against you. Despite this, I think it's a good, solid dice-rolling game that should be pretty easy to introduce non-gamers too. Plus it plays up to six, which can be hard to find. But it does take a bit too long for what it is.
4/16/10: The more I play Alhambra Dice, the better I feel about the fact that I traded it away. It's decent and an interesting translation of Alhambra to a Yahtzee-clone, but it is a good 30-45 minutes longer than it should be, and the last round feels largely superfluous, particularly with 5-6 people. There just isn't enough to do with your last couple rolls, particularly if the dice aren't feeling agreeable. It's alright for once in awhile, but I can think of Yahtzee clones I prefer.

item.name: Alien Frontiers: The Mind Control Helmet
Anachronism
item.comment: Was introduced to this by a CCG-playing friend. I don't know what to say about it, exactly. It's odd. It's a CCG, but your deck consists of five cards. Basically, it plays out like a very mini-mini-mini wargame, with you and your opponent sidestepping back and forth across a small grid to try to flank each other. It struck me as kind of dry and bland, to be honest, but it's obviously someone else's cup of tea.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment:
Great party game but I feel like it needs to be played in short spurts rather than over and over again; around the third or fourth round, I think the uniqueness tends to wear off. Like The Big Idea, most of the fun here is in the bickering and debating about why "Sweat Socks" are more "Luminescent" than the "Desert," or whatever. So it boils down to, largely, a BSing game. But it's definitely fun when taken at that.
Also, totally honestly, better with some alcohol.

item.name: Aquädukt
item.comment: Had some neat aspects, and I like that the d20-rolling adds some randomness to your building placements, keeping the game fairly light on the brain-burning (and keeps people from over-analyzing their turns). The water-laying concept is neat, but Santiago does it better.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
Oh Arkham, I will never stop singing your praises.
So, in the interest of full disclosure: I love co-op games. If you do not like co-op games, please remove yourself from the vicinity of Arkham Horror.
Okay, now, let's get this out of the way. There are flaws in Arkham Horror. Even one who loves it as much as I has to admit this. The rules are numerous and have strange facets and interactions that could fill a novel with errata and FAQs. There are seventeen gazillion little fiddly bits, so you will need lots of plastic bags and/or pill cases and/or fishing tackle boxes. FFG churns out expansions for this at a steady pace, meaning that if you're a completionist or an expansion addict (Hi, that's me), you will be broke and have a closet taken up by this game alone. Finally, it's lengthy; it often takes 3-4 hours, and can easily exceed that when you're playing with near the maximum number of players.
Now, on to the good stuff. This game drips with theme and tension. It can be brutal when you're unlucky, and brutal even when you're lucky (though sometimes, mysteriously, goddesses and gods will smile on you and you will have a smooth game). There are tons of decisions to be made, and it's often never clear which is the right choice. This makes it, I think, more enjoyable for newbies than some other co-ops, because there's a lot less of the "Loudest and most analytical person running everyone else's turn" problem. It's hard to say "You should go here and do this" when, really, anywhere you go could either kill you or give you a great item depending on whether the game hates you or not (Hint: it hates you). You have to approach it as a fun experience and be ready to lose. Like a good role-playing game, you leave with lots of funny and exciting memories that you can be discussing for weeks to come (like the time your investigator nearly threw themselves into a well to their death on their FIRST ENCOUNTER, or the time your investigator got beaten up by a monster and woke up in the hospital with.. Tuberculosis?!?).
I love this game so much. :3
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: There is some necessary color-distinguishing going on here, but it's a co-op, which makes asking someone or putting someone else in charge of the color-dependent parts fairly easy. In particular, Arkham location encounter and Other World gate cards are color-coded. The former I've managed to adapt to by getting good at matching the pictures of the locations on the backs of cards rather than colors--this is a fairly necessary move since the colors are often very similar shades of blue-purple versus straight purple or yellow-green versus sickly yellow. The Other World cards come in four colors--red, green, blue, and yellow--with no other pictures for distinguishing. Luckily, I find that they're pretty bright shades that I can tell apart, but people with more advanced red-green colorblindness may have trouble.
UPDATE 3/3/09: Okay, I finally admitted it. I downgraded AH from a 10 to a 9. I have to admit that there are a few problems with the game that are really starting to impede my enjoyment. 1) The difficulty is incredibly inconsistent. We win some games without breaking a sweat. Others are long, tense, wonderfully drawn-out battles. Others are forgone conclusions that manage to still stretch over hours. It's hard to convince myself to spend the large amount of time to teach, setup, and play the game when I'm not even sure if it will be hard enough to feel climactic and enjoyable.
2.) Fiddliness. This is FFG at the height of their bizarre obsession with overproduction. Setup and tear-down take FOREVER. Digging through billions of chits--and, yes, I'm well-organized, it's not like I have them all in a giant heap--gets annoying. It's not a game-breaking problem but it's frustrating. If I had a devoted cat-free room where I could leave the game set up I wouldn't be so bothered, but, y'know. Not that rich. Yet.
3.) Occasionally stagnant. This goes with the inconsistent difficulty thing. There will be times where the game just.. sits. You're at more or less an impasse--no one has any good options, they're trapped behind monsters and constantly being sent to the hospital or something, and yet the game isn't advancing, no new gates opening. Maybe it's clear that you're going to lose or win, but it could take another hour to get there, even if only the most wild act of [deity] could change that. It occasionally goes on far too long in this way.
I still love the game. It's still a great -experience-, but as a game it has some serious downsides, and some more recent co-ops (particularly Ghost Stories) have hurt my desire to play Arkham as much.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Curse of the Dark Pharaoh Expansion
item.comment:
I'd say this is the weakest out of the current expansions that I've played (CotP, KiY, DH). This is a small-box expansion, meaning it only contains items, allies, spells, skills, and encounters and Mythos. No new locations, investigators, or GOOs. There are some nasty encounters and Mythos cards that can vastly increase the difficulty (if I get the Mummies rumor again I will scream), but overall it doesn't feel like it adds a lot. Take this with a grain of salt, since I've only played one game with -just- CotP extra and no other expansions. But it just doesn't seem to distinguish itself too much. That said, if all you want are new encounters and no new mechanics, then this is a great expansion for you.
The one unique thing that I -do- appreciate about CotP is the very few, awful dual-color gate deck cards. These force you to, if you're in the wrong Other World, face off one-on-one against a GOO or be devoured. It adds a serious amount of tension to venturing into R'lyeh when you know that there's a small chance that you will have to fight Cthulhu by yourself.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Dunwich Horror Expansion
item.comment:
The best of the Arkham expansions I've played (CotP, KiY, DH). This is a big box, so it has what I really want from an expansion: new characters, new GOOs, new locations, and new mechanics. It adds a lot to the game:
-The extra small board has several new locations, two new Other Worlds, and a new monster-limit-esque danger to look out for; if you let too many monsters wander around Dunwich, eventually they'll wake up an awful monster. -A new monster type (Stalking) is introduced. -Several of the new characters are awesome (the handyman!), though some seem a bit weak. -The new GOOs are brutal. I haven't dared to try most of them, their descriptions scare me so much. -THE INJURY/MADNESS DECKS. I don't think I'd ever play without these again. They are a more enjoyable and less frustrating alternative to the "Lose half of your everything" effect when you're knocked out or go insane; instead, you get all your life or sanity back (instead of wasting an extra turn in the hospital/asylum to do so) and draw what is, essentially, an anti-Skill; some sort of permanent handicap. Too many of these can kill you, but I find that they're more enjoyable than losing half your stuff, which is just frustrating. -Finally, it does up the difficulty a decent amount, mostly because it's a lot easier to lose by the "too many gates open at once" rule with 9 new locations on the board. But it's a nice increase in difficulty, not a ROCKS FALL EVERYONE DIES type that just feels mean.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Kingsport Horror Expansion
item.comment:
The right way to do an Arkham big-box expansion. Instead of depending upon gates opening on the extra board to keep it relevant, like Dunwich does, Kingsport has a unique mechanism that makes it a necessary force to keep in check regardless of how watered down the Mythos deck may be.
The new investigators have some interesting facets; I'm amazed that they can keep coming up with new characters that still seem distinct. The new GOOs are frightful, and the Epic Battle deck provides interesting flavor to the end battle; personally, I didn't find the end battle "too easy," but it did come off as a bit bland. The flavor text especially on the Epic Battle cards (and the addition to specific cards for each GOO) adds a lot to the experience. The Heralds are equally dangerous, and the addition of Guardians to allow for difficulty tweaking depending on your group and setup.
Overall, I heartily recommend KH, especially if you're looking for a good difficulty bump. I haven't tried combining it with other expansions, but I think it would fare well with deck-watering based on its construction. Hopefully if there is an Innsmouth, it will follow such a pattern.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Black Goat of the Woods Expansion
item.comment: Not sure on this one. I don't enjoy the small-box expansions nearly as much as the big-box ones. But on the other hand, we all know I'm ultimately helpless to Arkham expansions.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Curse of the Dark Pharaoh Expansion (Revised Edition)
Arkham Horror: The King in Yellow Expansion
item.comment:
This is the expansion to buy if you just think Arkham is too darned easy. It's a small-box, which means no new characters or GOOs, just cards (encounters, mythos, allies, items, etc.). And it is HARSH.
First, you have the addition of the King in Yellow play; some Mythos cards that could cause a sudden loss if too many of them are drawn and can only be counteracted by incredibly painful means (such as discarding two seals from the board). (I will note, though, that even when playing with just the KiY expansion, this rarely seems to play a major role in the game. I suspect it mostly is only a concern when you're doing the "Traveling Performance" version.)
Second, you have the King in Yellow Herald, which finally gives the Terror Track some much-needed bite, rather than just using it as an ally-discarder. This is probably my favorite aspect of the KiY expansion: when the Herald is in play, the Terror Track is of nearly as much concern as the Doom Track, rather than just being that fiddly thing that lets us clear out the Outskirts occasionally.
And, finally, the cards in KiY are just mean. Whenever I draw a particularly bad Mythos--one of those ones that makes you wonder if you ran over the game designer's beloved pet or something--it's usually a KiY.
I think this is a great expansion for a small-box one, though I obviously prefer big-boxers. If you're gonna get a small box AH expansion, get this and not CotP, for sure. This one really cranks up the difficulty, so we use it when we feel like the game's being too easy on us.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Lurker at the Threshold Expansion
item.wishlistcomment: Not totally sure I need another Arkham expansion, but...

item.name: Around the World in 80 Days
item.comment: Only played once, with three people. I can see this being a good family game, but I felt like there weren't really enough important decisions to be made during this. But for filler, it's not half-bad, and I've heard when it's a full five-person game, it's much more cutthroat and interesting.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: There's nothing -wrong- with Attika, but it just doesn't grab me. I don't know what else to say about it, really. I like the stylized art style, but the game itself just does nothing to me.

item.name: Attribute
item.comment: This one was a surprise! I got this in the Chain of Generosity along with a copy of RftG, and I had sort of expected it to be one of those games that never got played in my group. Party games, in general, are not terribly popular at game nights. But Attribute's come out a few times and has been a blast to play whenever it has. Sure, the scoring system's a bit weird and people who are dealt a black sheep have a possible scoring advantage over those who are dealt a white one. But who cares? The game's filled with laughter and crazy across-the-table slapping, and people generally ask to let the game continue an extra round or two, which means it's got to be pretty good in my book.

item.name: BANG! The Bullet!
item.comment: Bang! is a decent combatative screw-your-neighbor game, and the hidden roles system works well. But it can tend to drag (the expansions help with this with the round-based special effects that end up shortening things). When it's a half hour, it's a fun trash-talking game of shooting your friends. When it's an hour or more with a lot of people, it's a bit tedious.

item.name: Batavia
item.comment: It's a fun sort of... uh, I'm not sure what to call it, exactly. I guess set-majority game? With pirates? It's... strange. The mechanics are a little all over the place and seem totally unrelated to the theme, but that doesn't mean it's a bad game. It's basically a lot of struggling to make sure you have the most cards in a certain type when you want them and then making sure that when the pirates attack your card-suit of choice is not that one that gets washed out. It's clever and interesting, and I'd definitely give it another go (with 5, especially--it seems like one of those games that would suffer with less players), but it's overall a bit bland and lacking in anything that really makes me go "wow."

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
Battlestar takes the semi-cooperative, "There's a traitor (or two) among us" mystique of Shadows over Camelot and fixes many of the problems with its medieval predecessor. By making the [-]Progression of Evil[/-] Crisis step often a group task, it eliminates the lengthy downtime that can come with games of 5 or more players. By giving Cylons their own section of the board with various powers, it eliminates the often-boring "Add a siege engine, steal a card" revealed-traitor step of SoC. Instead of accusations, people are throwing each other into and out of the Brig left and right, and stripping each other of their titles. The Brig itself is a bit like the Captured! card from Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company but without the possibility of throwing a player out of the game for an hour or so by allowing them limited interaction and their own attempts to leave. Making most of the important information on the board (rather than what's in people's hands) makes table-talking much less tempting and necessary-feeling than SoC and keeps people from being mindlessly stuck on the same quest for several turns. Finally, Executive Orders make accomplishing things more possible even when there's five people between you and your next turn. (As an aside, I appreciate that I, someone who has never seen the show, could enjoy this game as much as those who did. Sure, the quotes and flavor text were lost on me, but the game itself was still incredibly fun; I didn't feel left out by my lack of familiarity with the source material at all.)
The game isn't without its flaws. First and foremost, it could've used a few more weeks in playtesting and editing. The rulebook makes finding certain rules a chore, especially since it has one of the most useless indices I've encountered. Some post-publication FAQs REALLY should have been caught before the game came out (how did NO ONE notice the Executive Order loop?). Fighting [-]siege engines[/-] raiders is a bit boring compared to other things you could be doing, and you get sort of stuck out in space--it's not worth spending an entire turn coming back to the ship to do something else. Also, since everything in space disappears whenever you jump and pilots get shunted back into the hangar, it can often feel, as a pilot, like you were just about to blow up some serious Cylon butt when you get teleported back into the ship. And again. And again. So being a pilot's a bit thankless. But overall the flaws are few, and the game is addictive and really well-done. My rating's currently a 9 for it--tied with SoC--but I can see that increasing as I see if I feel the same after more plays.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: Daybreak Expansion
item.wishlistcomment: Preorder only as far as I know

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment:
4/16/10: Decent auction/risk-taking game that has some aesthetic similarities to Lord of the Rings (the co-op), but little else in common. My game was 4p and was decent but felt a little lighter than I expected; I'm hoping that with 5p it would be a bit tighter. As it stands, my concerns are that: clockwise auctions seem to largely come down to someone winning a absurdly large Risk pull of 3-4 symbols, and that Risks rarely seem NOT worth taking, especially with the many opportunities to void one's scratches. I suspect some of this was unfamiliarity with the game--I think we tended to go whole-hog into many auctions without thinking about what lay ahead and what our priorities were, and we didn't know the relative worth of prizes. That said, I will say that it felt somewhat unique and interesting enough that I want to give it another couple go-rounds.
One major complaint outside of gameplay, though. I love the 3-sided board, that's really aesthetically interesting. But why in the name of all that is holy is everything related to the game so freaking TINY on it? I understand wanting to leave room for the neat art, but when we feel tempted to bust out some old-grandparent reading glasses to make out icons, something has gone wrong in the graphic design department.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
This game is all over the place. Sometimes it's too long, sometimes it's very short. Sometimes it's a close, down-to-the wire win, sometimes it's a complete blowout. Sometimes it's interesting, sometimes it drags. I play it fairly often for its rating because it's hard to find good 6-player games, and this one scratches a particular itch.
The good: it's a nice bit of B-horror-movie fun. Some of the scenarios are incredibly interesting and tense (like a recent one I played that had the house collapsing as the heroes struggled to exorcise it). The random-traitor setup allows for some light screwing-everyone-over fun without the desperate keeping-secrets tenseness of Shadows, which can be a welcome respite.
The bad: Oh, god, attack of the zillions of indistinguishable bits. Why not have a few generic bits that say "Monster" or something, rather than 10,000 little circles, some of which say "Rat" and some "Dog" and some "Aliens from beyond the grave"? It makes it impossible to find what you're looking for unless you have a really OCD storage system. The scenarios can be terribly unbalanced, or they can be really boring for the traitor (one had me doing nothing but, I'm not joking, reading results from a die-roll table every turn to the heroes. That's it).
It can still be a decent game, but it could desperately use a reprint with some rules clarifications and overhauls and a solution to the bit problem. I'm not sure it's worth the slavering, pay-100-dollars status that its out of print nature has bestowed upon it.

item.name: The Big Idea
item.comment: A decently enjoyable BS/fast-talking game in the spirit of Apples to Apples, but unfortunately the play mechanics of investments and payoffs don't seem to mesh well with the improv sales-pitch-making that is the true fun of the game.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Very good 2-player-only game. Played it to death a couple years ago.

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment:
Honestly, got this version only because regular Blokus wasn't available when I was shopping. Personally, I like Blokus with the squares better, but "they" say that Trigon's better for three players (I haven't had any experience with regular Blokus for three, so I can't say).
Whatever version you get, Blokus is a nice, easy-to-teach abstract placement game that should only take 20-30 minutes (unless some people--you know who you are--overthink every turn).

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager – The Card Game
Blue Moon City
item.comment:
For some reason, I wasn't particularly impressed with BMC the first time I played it, but after a second try I found it to be an enjoyable and short game. It's sort of hard to categorize--I guess it would be building and resource management?--but it has pretty art (re-used from Blue Moon), good mechanics, and is easy to teach and understand.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: I have a bit of trouble with this game, particularly with figuring out whether my cards match a particular tile's color. I've been told that after awhile you will get used to knowing which races are which colors and that will help. But, still, a little warning here on that note.

item.name: Blue Moon City: Expansion Tile Sets 1 & 2
Bohnanza
item.comment: I'd have to give it another shot, but right now it seems a bit bland to me. I like the interesting hand-management mechanics, but the ruthless "What do I get from it?" trading just got on my nerves for some reason.

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
item.comment: I was hesitantly invited to join in a game (hesitantly because they were afraid the media tie-in name would scare me off), and I excitedly joined after hearing some good about it from the 'Geek. And it's not bad. If I didn't have better one evil vs. four good games to compare it to (such as Last Night on Earth), I might have thought more of it. But it just didn't really pop for me. This might be due to the fact that the Evil guy was the only one who'd played and our game felt accordingly pretty misbalanced and frustrating. I also think that someone who is more devoted to the series would get more from the game--I'd seen Season One and that was it when I played this, and so I had no idea what most of the cards were referring to, and thus didn't get much nostalgia value out of it. There were some fun and interesting points to it--the Moon mechanic was interesting and would have been more fun if not for the fact that we could barely ever get it to advance and whenever we did the Evil Master would turn it back to the beginning, so Oz barely ever got to slash around as a Werewolf and we didn't ONCE get to make it daytime. But it overall felt a bit lackluster for me. I'd play again if asked, and I hope that maybe other scenarios than the Season One could make it more interesting, but as it stands I wasn't terribly impressed.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: Hard for me to rate. The game itself is pretty enjoyable, mostly because you spend the whole time re-enacting John Woo-esque standoffs. But I personally--and I know that I'm in the minority--am really bothered by the racial caricatures that pass for characters, and so I won't be playing this game again.

item.name: Cabby!
item.comment: I hang onto this because I feel guilty getting rid of something so old, basically. It has an interesting concept; a roll-and-mover with flexible rules, but each player has a police car to "catch" those that flex the rules and penalize them for doing so. But the times I've played it, it's been a bit slow and not as enjoyable as it could've been. Maybe a bunch of house-ruling could make something better from it. I should take pics for GG someday.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Carcassonne recently shot up to become one of my favorite games after a bunch of one-on-one plays with my partner. This is a simply fantastic game; simple and fairly easy to teach, friendly-looking and colorful, but rewarding of a lot of thought and downright cut-throat when it comes down to it. My partner even introduced it to my parents-in-law, and now they have their own copy that they play regularly, too! A beautiful and elegant game. I enjoy it most two-player, since it tends to take a bit longer with more players (only because people think harder about their turns and aren't able to plan ahead as much), but fun no matter what. I honestly don't see getting too many expansions, I think they'd ruin the nice simple-but-difficult feel the game currently has.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: Though I swore to myself I wouldn't pick up any expansions to Carcassonne, because I didn't want to mess with perfection, I saw this in a math trade and my expansion addict gave in for the chance to try the highest-rating expansion for Carc. And I'm pleased! It does make the game a bit longer--it felt a bit more draggy than usual, but that may be a fluke--but Inns & Cathedrals adds some interesting new elements without bogging down the game in too many extra rules. (Contrast Carcassonne - The Count of Carcassonne, which I also received in the math trade, and haven't yet tried but am not terribly pleased with how much extra fiddliness the rules seem to imply.) All the new features do are make certain roads and cities double-or-nothing bets, essentially. This allows for some giant scoring opportunities and some incredibly evil moves (your opponent making a big city that will score big even if it's incomplete? Shove a cathedral on it and add a few roads toward it to make it hard to complete, and it'll be worth nothing at the end!) Plus, the big meeples give some interesting dynamics by allowing you to over-protect certain scoring features or horn in and take over fields more easily. It will take some adjusting to the new game--my partner noted that our internal Carc clocks were off this first game, and we started doing our usual end-game tactics too soon because we weren't used to the additional tiles--but I don't think I'll be taking this expansion out anytime soon. (Which is good, because I got the tiles that aren't marked so I'd have to spend a lot of time on the Geek trying to separate them.)

item.name: Carcassonne: King & Scout
item.comment: Came with my copy of Carc (well, the non-Hunters-and-Gatherers parts of the expansion). The normal tiles are just mixed in and work fine (I love that two-city crossover one). We rarely use the robber and king tiles--while they add some interesting tension and a bit of bluffing/pushing about who can finish the biggest road/city, I don't find the extra scoring and time spent counting how big things are worth any potential benefits. I doubt I'll use that part of the expansion much.

item.name: Carcassonne: The River
item.comment: Came with my copy of Carc, and we use it pretty much every time we play now. Not only does it keep the whole city from being one giant field, but it also gives some nice tension where you can stake some claims early on but don't have a chance to immediately finish them. Gives everyone a shot at getting a farmer in. This one doesn't take much work to add and I feel it positively impacts the game, so I tend to use it as much as possible, only avoiding it sometimes when teaching new people.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons: Winter Cards
Catan
item.comment: I know this is the classic gateway game, and I like some of the mechanics, but I just find the base Catan a bit bland for my taste. You should try it at least once, since it's a classic and has some neat mechanics, but I much prefer Struggle for Rome, which uses the same mechanics in a more streamlined and directed way. If you're going to play regular Catan, at least add Cities & Knights, which adds some more good decisions and available routes to resources (e.g. bonus cards).

item.name: Catan Dice Game
item.comment: Played with the rules as written, CDG is just as solitary as Yahtzee but, I found, with fewer important decisions to make. It was fun in an extremely filler-ish way, but was nothing special. The official variant, however, looks interesting, and I'd give it another shot with that. Either way, it'll still be glorified Yahtzee, but there's nothing wrong with just rolling dice for the sake of rolling 'em sometimes.

item.name: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome
item.wishlistcomment: I like this game a decent amount but am put off by Mayfair's pricing policies. :(

item.name: Catan: Cities & Knights
item.comment: I find Catan by itself more than a bit bland; there's just not enough going on. But the resource system of Cities & Knights, combined with the bonus cards one can accumulate, adds a very nice layer to the game that makes it more enjoyable. Still nothing I'd ever want to own--mostly I just play it on AsoBrain when I have nothing else to do--but it's something I wouldn't mind playing once in awhile.

item.name: Cavum
item.comment: Oooough. On one hand, there are some interesting things going on here. And I tend to find "You only get X number of actions" games, like La Citta, interesting in a brain-burny sort of way. But what we have here is a game that, I think, could make ANYONE into [i]that[/i] AP person, who has to rethink every turn seven times. It's quite fiddly, though after a couple rounds it becomes a bit smoother. Overall, I just didn't get the level of enjoyment I'd expect from something that requires that much painstaking forethought. Give me Le Havre or Caylus any day. It's interesting and I would recommend it toward a certain sect of people who enjoy 2 hour AP fests, but I'm not willing to invest the amount of time to teach (which is rough with some difficult to communicate rules) and play this for the amount of fun it will give, generally, unless someone asked me to play it.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment:
Oof. I have a hard time determining how I feel about Caylus.
I think the game itself is fantastic. This is one of the best "multiple paths to victory" Euro-games I've seen. The worker placement mechanics work extremely well, there is a constant scarceness of resources and money that keeps the game tense, and the fact that you earn points from opponents using your buildings (and vice versa) adds an amazing amount of tactics and strategy to the game. The board is pretty, the provost mechanic adds some important interaction, the bailiff keeps the game from reaching a stalemate... I can't imagine the amount of work that went into perfecting the design on Caylus.
That said, I don't enjoy playing it very often. I think the main problem is this: there are very few other games I have seen that inspire quite as much analysis paralysis as Caylus. I think the game itself is partly to blame by its design: the fact that you don't get resources until the end of the turn, and you need very specific combinations of resources to work on the castle means that people spend countless minutes dithering "Wait, by this point I'll have two cloth and three stone, and then I'm trading the stone for two food, and... wait, let me start over."
I don't think I will -ever- agree to five-player Caylus again without a chess clock or something. I like Caylus a lot, but it should be at most a ninety-minute game; past that I'm getting jittery and bored with it. Unfortunately, it can tend to go onto two to two-and-a-half hours, and I just don't find it interesting enough to keep my attention that long.
So, in summary: fantastic game, needs to come packaged with turn timers.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: The "food" and "stone" cubes are pretty hard to distinguish. This is even worse on the buildings where the tiny pink and grey cubes are in the costs--it can take some squinting and good lighting to tell these apart. Might want to mark these up or ask other players.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World: The Horned Rat Expansion
Chez Geek
item.comment:
The Chez games, like the Munchkin series, have a fantastic sense of humor; SJgames know what they're doing on that front. Even after several plays, the card combinations that come up still elicit a good chuckle. Even the game theme--competing with your roommates to see who can slack off the most--is entertaining. The problem is that the mechanics simply don't feel like they mesh all that well. There's nothing too interesting going on here from a game design standpoint.
That said, as a beer-and-pretzels game or one you'd use with people who aren't big gamers, you could do worse.
item.conditiontext: Played a few dozen times but cards are in very good shape. Still have rules, but no box (kept in baggies). Would prefer to trade with Chez Goth but will consider splitting them up.

item.name: Chez Goth
item.comment: My comments from Chez Geek pretty much carry over here. The only new mechanic--gloom--rarely came up for us when we played, as we combined Goth with Geek and that tended to water it out to a large extent.
item.conditiontext: Played a few dozen times but cards are in very good shape. Still have rules, but no box (kept in baggies). Would prefer to trade with Chez Geek but will consider splitting them up.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: Really interesting train-building/investment game. Reminds me a bit of Imperial but without the wargame stuff and more direct influence on the state of your shares. I'll be interested to try again with a better knowledge of the worth of things.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: Wow. Points for originality here. A game that maintains much of the same barely-constrained-chaos feeling of Fluxx, but manages to be structured enough to avoid some of the frustration of the latter. Well done theme and amusing cards round it out well. It definitely has its own unique feel. Winning often seems to happen by accident, because someone unknowingly set the timeline to your history. The mechanics are pretty simplistic (just draw one play one) but it's always a good laugh of a game, and it doesn't tend to drag too long. Good filler game for a larger group.

item.name: Clue: The Great Museum Caper
item.conditiontext: Game is complete, box is in worn but still serviceable condition. A good number (a couple dozen?) maps for the thief remain. Either needs to be a trade from someone nearby for a pickup/no-ship or needs to be traded for something pretty amazing, since it's so bulky.

item.name: Code 777
item.conditiontext: Not an official copy: two Artscow decks (one of numbers, one of questions) for a PnP copy made while the game was out of print.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment:
What a great little 20-30 minute filler game. Like Carcassonne, it lulls people in with its bright colors and friendly-looking chameleons, but this is a harsh drafting/screw-your-neighbor set-collection game. The game is MADE by the scoring mechanism, which penalizes you for spreading yourself across too many colors; any sets you have past your best three are negative points at the end. While the rules suggest playing several rounds in a row and adding scores, Lost Cities-style, I find that this functions well as a single, stand-alone game (in fact, it's a decent enough length that usually once in a row is enough). It's incredibly quick and easy to teach and catch onto, so that new people have a decent chance of playing well their first time. Easy to introduce family and non-gamers to.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: I avoided this game for awhile due to its name, but great news: it is totally and utterly colorblind-FRIENDLY. All the cards have some background "texture" (gravelly-looking, wood patterning, etc.) that make them easy to distinguish even when colors are similar. Kudos to the makers for this smart move.

item.name: Coloretto Amazonas
item.comment:
Only played this once, but I liked it much less than its non-Amazonian counterpart. Instead on focusing on correctly drafting cards to communal "trucks" (terminology I got from playing Zooloretto and use for lack of a better term here) for gathering like Coloretto, Amazonas instead focuses on building up your own personal trucks and directly screwing with your opponents trucks. This direct combatativeness messes with the simple elegance of the original, I think, and also makes the game seem to go much more slowly. Progress is fleeting, and my experience was that very few people ever finished a total collection, and those who did were pretty much winners by default.
That said, my partner enjoyed this just as much as original Coloretto, so YMMV.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: Boy I WANT to really like a game this pretty. But Colosseum seems to go on for -far- too long for what it is. And, honestly, I don't like that you have to decide what you're doing for the entire game after the first or second round. The game's a bit better if the you make the "trading turns" into a free-for-all timed trading period. But it just doesn't click well with me. Plus, I really don't like games where your final score is based entirely on a single play (see Power Grid). I like feeling like I'm accumulating and building to something. While it's true your last performance is usually your best, I don't like knowing that I might really hit my best game on the third or fourth turn, and the rest of the game will end up being pointless for me if so. Maybe there's some hidden magic here I'm missing, but despite how beautiful the game is, it just doesn't do anything for me.

item.name: Confusion: Espionage and Deception in the Cold War
Container
item.comment: Oh gawwwwwd. So dry I could drain a lake after playing. May be good for people who like economic simulators, but I thought it was the most dry and mechanical exercise in supply and demand ever.

item.name: Crokinole
item.wishlistcomment: It's totally out of everyone's price range, but a high-quality Crokinole board like [url=http://www.hilinski.net/woodgames/crokinole.html]a Hilinski board[/url] would be amazing.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Defenders of the Realm: Global Effects Cards
Defenders of the Realm: Hero Expansion #1
Defenders of the Realm: The Barbarian
Defenders of the Realm: The Dragon Expansion
Diamant
item.wishlistcomment: Also sold under the name Incan Gold; either is good

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: An interesting area-majority sort of game that gets a bit bogged down in its own mechanisms. I think that having my first game be 6-player kind of skews my view of the game, but while I like the combination of Caylus-esque worker placement with a sort of El Grande type of area majority, the constant need to recalculate who is dominant, and the poor choice in vocabulary (dominant vs. dominance, the choice of the word "species" to mean a single cube, which is awfully counter-intuitive) cause some problems that bog the game down. Games have to be [b]awfully[/b] interesting and strong to keep me engaged for 3+ hours, and I wasn't feeling that here. I think with the correct group of people and a smaller size--4 seems about right for this--I could enjoy DS, but I don't really feel the need to try it again.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: I've been lucky enough to be in on some of the later, near-final-build playtesting (read: playing and going "I really don't have any complaints except that I can't buy it yet") of this game, and I predict it will be an incredibly hot item toward the end of the year. If you take attempting to build a really good deck for a CCG, and make an awesome game around that feeling, you get Dominion. I've only played three-player games of it, but I assume that two and four work just as well. Plays in about 20-30 minutes, generally, except that you can never play just one game of it. Not quite a 10 in my book yet, I'm reserving final judgment for when I've played the final build, but for right now I'm incredibly impressed with it.

item.name: Dominion: Prosperity
item.wishlistcomment: Expected to come out Aug/Sep/Oct, so pre-orders only at the moment.

item.name: Downton Abbey: The Board Game
item.comment: [IMG]http://24.media.tumblr.com/a24c9bab104ad6b4fe6bff522a01ea02/tumblr_ml8d7xlsT21qiip6uo1_400.gif[/IMG]

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: I feel like I'm going to have to play this several more times to be able to make a fair assessment of it. Right now it feels far too complicated and fiddly for what it is, but thankfully it only plays to 5 VPs and so doesn't take too long. I think, like chess, it's going to take a lot of getting used to in order to play well, and if I were playing an experienced Dungeon Twister I'd get slaughtered. I'm not totally sure I feel like the game is worth all the effort of getting fantastic at, but I'll give it a few more shots to see if it grows on me.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
The Dutch Golden Age
item.comment: I'm kind of surprised I liked this one as much as I did, since it tends to be the sort of game I find boring. But I was drawn into playing by the stylish art and bits, and ended up really enjoying myself. The roll-and-move mechanic to add some semi-random income kept the game from feeling too scripted, and there was a nice variety of viable approaches. I am a little bothered that a game that seems to promise multiple paths to victory has one (Grain) that seems to be a necessary component for winning, but it was still quite fun and I'd play again.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: 4/23/10: I'm not sure I get the insane love this game is getting lately. It's not [b]bad[/b], but it's not super-spectacular, either. There are aspects that I feel like I should like a lot--I'm a big fan of developing a civilization by building up tech, and games where it feels like there are many valid strategies. But something just feels really quite bland here. Plus I think the board's graphic design is confusing and unattractive (though the player boards and cards are nice), and the setup is annoying. I'll play it again, it's interesting and I do get that "Next time I'll get it right" that some of my favorite games (Through the Ages, Le Havre) give me, but something about Endeavor just doesn't really catch me.

item.name: Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre
Escape from the Aliens in Outer Space
Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Fairy Tale
item.comment:
Nice quick little drafting game. Other than drafting, there is fairly minimal interaction, but the drafting plays such a significant role in the game that it doesn't feel like multi-player solitaire. You are given enough space in your hand to effectively hate-draft (unlike, say, Notre Dame, where you can only spare one space for a card you don't need), and the few interaction cards (that make opponents flip cards or "hunt") keep the game lively enough as cards are played. I will say there's a learning curve on this one, it's hard to play effectively when you don't know the cards very well and how they interact. Thankfully, drafting is alternated in direction, so you have less of the "Winner is sitting to the left of the new person" effect.
4/23/10: After a long break and coming back, Fairy Tale is a nice filler but a lot less impressive than I thought when I was first getting into games. Basically, there is little to no game here without the drafting; this isn't a [b]problem[/b] per se but does make it a bit of a one-trick pony that eventually wears off. Still, for filler, it isn't bad.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: Outrageously fun. Some simple, well-structured rules by FF (I'm amazed at this man's grasp of good mechanics) create a chaotic, screw-your-neighbor race that generates tons of laughter and groans as one player makes an ingenious move that dooms several smug opponents. I have such a fantastic time playing this game.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
Firefly: The Game – Pirates & Bounty Hunters
For Sale
item.comment: Fun enough filler game. I'm awful at it, but that doesn't mean it isn't enjoyable. Cute art, goes by quickly, and has a nice sense of tension due to the fact that you never get any income and a press-your-luck element from not wanting to be the person who pays their full bid. Good for light-gaming groups.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment: Don't feel like I've played enough to really have a good impression of it yet. I think with 4-6 this could become really addictive, but I'm not quite sure -why-.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: Eh. It's not bad. It'd be a great game for teaching addition skills to kids. It's a pretty typical Knizia game (complete with one of a "If you have the most of this color you can throw yours out" rule) that feels an awful lot like 6 Nimmt! without the blind bidding (which is really the best part of 6 Nimmt!). Not bad for a short filler, and I'd happily suggest it for a children's game, but it didn't do much for me.

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment:
Underneath the sex, drugs, and blasphemy, this is a really solid auctioning game. However, the aforementioned 'naughty' nature really makes it a fun game for groups of 5-6 in particular, and serves as a good way to introduce people to a meatier game while keeping the level of enjoyability high. There are some really incredibly well-thought mechanics here (particularly the cell phones, and the "Hit level 4 in one stat, lose all of another stat"). Even when you've seen the cards a bunch, the humor stays fresh for quite awhile (unlike the "Only funny once or twice" effect that tends to be the case in a lot of humor-based games), and there's nothing quite like getting your friend pregnant, breaking up with them, then getting back together just long enough to give them an STD and break up with them again. The cell phone mechanics are hard for new people to grasp at first, but once that's down, it's a really smooth, enjoyable game.
Edit after many plays: I would like this game a lot more if I wasn't the only one to firmly grasp the friends and cell phone rules. As it is I have to re-teach and/or provide two dozen rules clarifications per game, and it gets tiring.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment: Played twice now. The deduction portions of the game are neat, and things like the mixed Event deck are very unique and interesting. However, the game itself feels a bit dry and plodding in many ways, and the combat system just -fails- in my opinion. Absolutely boring dice-modified rock scissors paper that seems to too heavily encourage Dracula to just Escape(Mist) as much as possible. Maybe I'm missing some subtleties of it, but I've never been a fan of RPS mechanics, either. I'd play it now and then, but it's nothing I'd want to own. I think maybe I should just try Scotland Yard, since that is the part of the game I like best.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment:
I'd been slavering over Ghost Stories since reading the hype about it from Essen, and I bought it on an impulse when on a vacation in Seattle. Reading over the rules later in the hotel room, I started to feel a bit trepidatious; they were a bit confusingly written with some questionable translation, and overall the concept of the game seemed a bit too repetitive and simple to be fun. I know that a simple concept doesn't necessarily mean that a co-op game can't kick your butt (see Pandemic), but, anyway, I was starting to worry that I'd blown $50 and valuable suitcase space (we never check luggage, so this is always at a premium on vacation) on an overhyped release with nice production values. After about half of a game that I abandoned, I was even more worried, but still determined to give the game a fair shake.
Oh wow, am I glad I did. When played with four people, this is an unmerciful, immersive, and downright fantastic co-op. It can suffer from the "loudest player" problem that a lot of open-info co-ops do, but, honestly, I find that to be largely unavoidable in many co-ops. It's somewhat mitigated by the fact that, usually, EVERYTHING is going wrong, and so there's often several answers for a given turn, none of which are particularly clearly correct. Ghost Stories is now one of my favorite co-operative games, often inspiring "just one more try" when we've gotten our butts handed to us, which is high praise for a game that tends to run about 45-60 minutes (usually once in a row is enough for an hour-length game for my group and me).

item.name: Ghost Stories: The Guardhouse Expansion
item.comment:
Nice bit of extra replay in a tiny package. I thought the Guardhouse would be terribly overpowered, but, in fact, it's useful without being too unbalancing. I certainly prefer it to some Tiles, such as the Watchman's Beat or the Tea House, but its usefulness is limited (often because all 4 of the next ghosts are terrible, so reordering them doesn't help much). I COULD see this leading to a bit longer game if people use it frequently and very tightly analyze the next four ghosts (who is drawing each one, what the board will look like at each time to figure out where all the ghosts would go), but I doubt it should be too much of a problem.
I'd heard complaints that the new ghosts were too easy, as was the Wu Feng. Personally, I think they add a nice variety. Their danger is in the fact that they SEEM innocuous, so you focus more on things with Haunters or some of the Tormentors. And then suddenly you have two or three tiles being terrorized and you need them and it's too late to kill off the ghosts to free them. The Wu Feng can be brutal if he hits the wrong row. Much like, say, Howling Nightmare, how bad he is depends on the situation when he hits. While I'd still use just the base game for beginners, having some extra variability in the ghost and village setup helps give an awesome game extra staying power, and I'm all for that.
(On a cost/benefit analysis, though, I definitely would not pay the $20-25 I see people charging in the Marketplace for this. That's ludicrous. I'd say this is worth $10-15, depending on the amount you play the game and how much you may be burned out on the base set.)

item.name: Ghost Stories: The Village People Expansion
Give Me the Brain!
item.comment: Well, here's one, at least, that I didn't come in filled up on hype on. When this got broken out on New Years, I was fully prepared from the name and box for a humor-based barely-a-game card game, and that's about what I got. It's nothing terrible, but I didn't really find much of value in it, either. I didn't really find most of the cards all that amusing--as opposed to, say, Munchkin or Chez Geek, where I at least found the cards worth a chuckle or two--and the gameplay itself felt like the less enjoyable parts of Fluxx, where you end up forced to play cards you don't want to due to your situation. That and the fact that you may go a long time between turns due to brain-dropping and various screw-your-neighbor cards, and I just don't see much of a point to playing this. I'd say it's okay for killing time, but, honestly, I'd rather play Fluxx or some other filler in that time.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
Some people in my group love this game. I find it pretty much an all-around apathetic "meh" of an experience. The production quality is mediocre; I don't find the art as eye-gougingly painful as some of my compatriots, but I don't think it's good by any means, and the cards are extremely busy. This is the second recent game I've played with the giant chaotic discard pile mechanism (Mwahaha! being the other), and I find it somewhat distasteful. The mechanics are incredibly counterintuitive, and while I find some slight amusement in how incredibly overpowered nearly all the cards seem to be, I find that in practice it doesn't mesh well. (Like To Court the King, I sort of feel like the game resulted from a bunch of guys just sitting around going "You know what would be AWESOME? If there was a card that did this, but on CRACK!" with little regard to balance or flow.)
There are some little bits of genius in the game; I think the four-sided cards that function in four different ways depending on how they're placed under your mat are inventive, but the way that this is displayed is too busy and hard to make out. I'll play this when others want to, but only because it's short enough that I find it just a mild timewaster, rather than an exercise in frustration.

item.name: Goa
item.comment: This is a classic that I've amazingly never managed to play, though it's been on my "Want to Play" radar for quite awhile. I was a little wary coming into it--after a bad brush with Princes of Florence, I sometimes treat classics with caution, for fear that I will have too high expectations. In this case, however, no such kid gloves were necessary. Goa was an incredibly entertaining game, albeit a schizophrenic one. There are several different mechanics all cobbled together, and yet, amazingly enough, it works. The auction placement mechanism adds a lot of interactivity and tension, the semi-closed auctions provide an interesting method for obtaining income, and the tech-leveling system provided several different methods of approaching the game. Goa is one of those games where you don't have nearly enough turns to do everything you want, and it works very well within that genre. I'm surprised and pleased with this classic, and am looking forward to getting another game of it in sometime.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment:
Another game I'll have to play a couple more times to solidify my feelings. I'm not very good at area-control games, in general. But while I wasn't impressed with this at first, in retrospect I find that there are some nice mechanics going on here, it doesn't feel too heavy, and it ends in a fairly reasonable length of time.
The tower of hidden cubes adds a nice memory/press-your-luck component, as well as a last minute element of change before scoring that keeps scoring rounds more tense. The hidden-location rondels for each player allow for simultaneous secret actions in a concise (if slightly gimmicky) manner. The special action cards allow for some good interaction and screw-your-neighbor plays. I'm not a giant fan of the cube-farming mechanic (moving cubes from the provinces to your court), but it isn't nearly as omnipresent and annoying as it is in Notre Dame, so I'll let that slide.
I'd definitely play a couple more times, though it's not at the top of my to-do list. Maybe I'm just a sucker for cube-towers.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: Oh jeez, the green and brown cubes are nigh indistinguishable. WHY NOT BLACK AS A COLOR? SHEESH. So, yeah, this caused some issues in putting cubes in areas where I thought there was one other person with a lot of brown cubes when, in fact, the green and brown players were both there. Careful with this if you have color impairment!

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment:
A fun little filler with some depth, but not so much that it's inaccessible for non-gamers; you can only really look ahead possibly one or two turns, so there's not much room for over-analyzing. Has a high luck component, but I think it's a fun "Take that" sort of game.
Okay, I lied, there's pretty much no depth to it. But it's still a good take-that filler.

item.name: The Hanging Gardens
item.comment: This is a unique and interesting game. It essentially boils down to a set-collection game, but the interesting garden-building rules work quite well, and it has a nice push-your-luck element as you decided whether to hold out for larger pieces of land to put your temple on. It felt a bit dry and didn't really grab me, but was a well-made and interesting game.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: A very interesting brain-burner that has some definite similarities but is distinct enough to be judged on its own worth and not as any sort of copycat or revamp. Seriously agonizing decisions to be made due to a severe shortage of actions. Just as in many other games--including Agricola and Through the Ages--there is simply not NEARLY enough time to do what you want, so you have to make due with what you can. Lots of potential for min/maxing your moves, which makes me wary; that sort of game tends to lead to SEVERE AP problems, the like of which put me off of Caylus to a large extent. But hopefully people can learn to plan their turns ahead of time--it seems like downtime could become a serious problem otherwise in a many-playered game. Still, some really neat mechanics going on and a nice, satisfying feeling of having built an economy by the end. It may be too long for me to want to play often, but I enjoyed my first game of it.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: Neat little 2-player game but I tired of it pretty quickly.

item.name: Ilium
item.comment: It's alright for a quick filler sort of game, I guess. There are some interesting bits of tactics here, but--and y'all should know I'm not one to complain about a bit of randomness, so this has to be fairly annoying to have gotten my goat--the inability to decide whether you put down 1-3 workers really hurts any sort of real planning in the game. That makes it largely a bit too light for the amount of fiddliness it has. Just a bland Knizia with his Ingenious scoring.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment:
I wanted to like Imperial. I did. I had caught a whiff of the hype on BGG about it and thought that the Rondel sounded neat and some of the other mechanics could be cool. So I asked a friend to bring it to a recent game night, and we gave it a play. There was mass confusion at first as we struggled through the rules--even the people who'd played once or twice were having some trouble refreshing themselves--but the game flow was pretty simple once we got the hang of it. It's largely a war game with economic aspects in how it plays out (not in its win conditions, but we'll get there later), and I'm not much of a war game person, so it didn't grab me much there. The fact that we could steal control of countries from each other and, indeed, make it so someone really didn't have a turn at all was interesting. I mostly contented myself with running Germany into the ground (did I mention that I'm bad at war games?) and buying stocks from whatever country seemed to be doing well at the moment.
And... I won. I managed to [i]accomplish absolutely nothing of value[/i] the entire game, and still came in first place. And while I find that interesting, I also feel like it's a very cheap win. Yes, you can argue that I handled the game exactly as I should have, and that the others who were doing better on the war-game front had lost sight of the actual victory conditions, or whatever other argument you want to posit. But in the end, I just don't feel like it was a satisfying win for me, or probably for anyone else at the table. And I'd probably let that slide if I enjoyed the actual gameplay more, but I didn't. The Rondel was neat but nothing earth-shattering, and I'm just not big on moving armies around. I don't have a head for that sort of game and find myself just sort of blandly going through the motions when I play such. I'm sure for the right sort of person, Imperial is AWESOME. But I'm not that person.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: This was a surprise, in that I had been totally prepared to love this game. But I didn't; this felt just sort of "Meh" for reasons I can't quite put my finger on. There were some very interesting aspects, like the person track, but I just didn't quite feel like it was as terribly interesting as I had expected. I only played with 3 people, though, and I can see how this is a much more tight, cut-throat game with 4-5. I'd be willing to give it another shot with more players, but as it is it didn't do anything for me.

item.name: Infinite City: Guild Hall and Salvage Yard
Ingenious
item.comment: Played the online version a bunch and found this pretty enjoyable. Would be interested in giving it a shot in person.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
James Ernest's Totally Renamed Spy Game
item.comment: Boy, I enjoyed this a lot more in undergrad, before I was exposed to a lot more games. The theme's great, and the humor is spot-on to a large extent; the main fun in this game is building a ludicrous lair full of killer clowns armed with grapefruit squeezers or whatever. Unfortunately, it can tend to end up as a very boring affair of "I play a lair card and send a spy that I know is strong enough to blow up the lair of the person to my right. Then the next person does the same to me." After you've read through all the cards a few time so that they're not funny anymore, the game isn't nearly as enjoyable anymore (I find this is true for most of the Cheapass games I play, unfortunately).
item.conditiontext: Very good condition. Played probably a couple dozen times, but showing little wear on anything except the box, which is admittedly in somewhat poor shape; battered from going through a couple moves and some peeling art on the back.

item.name: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot
item.conditiontext: Very good condition; played approximately a dozen times.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: Growing Hunger
Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
Legend of the Five Rings
item.comment: Not bad for a CCG. Based on one play, I'm finding it a bit dense, though I understand there's a strong learning curve on this one. It's not bad, and I'm sure I'll end up playing it from time to time, but I just think it's sort of okay.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: A bunch of simple mechanisms that have been done before--and better--elsewhere, cobbled together with some ugly memory or knowing-the-game-ahead-of-time elements. Note to designers: If I feel like I actually have more workers to place than I have useful things to place them on, you're doing it wrong.

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
Lord of the Rings
item.comment: 2/23/08: We actually won! :D My partner (Sam) and I (Frodo) managed to through the ring in Mt. Doom with 86 points as our final score (base game only). 2/26/08: And a five-player win now. Everyone except Sam died, but, hey, that's a win! 78 points plus whatever the final shield was, we forgot to draw it.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings Trading Card Game
item.comment: Played this over Spring Break with a friend staying with us. I'd play it again if he wanted to, because he obviously loves it and wants to play it a lot, but I thought it was pretty mediocre CCG fare, to be honest. I'm not very well-versed in CCGs, mind you--I dabbled in Magic and the Star Wars CCG for awhile, and that's about it--but something about this just didn't feel too revolutionary. I did think the Twilight mechanic was clever; the Fellowship player essentially gives the forces of darkness fuel for spells whenever the Fellowship casts a spell, which is a nice balancing mechanic. But the whole affair felt very dry. And the fact that evil forces disappear at the end of every turn just does not sit well with me. I understand the mechanical issues present there, I think, and concede it's probably a logical game design decision. But it never feels right when playing, and it takes away any sense of triumph the Fellowship player might experience at killing an enemy. Not a terrible game, but it just didn't seem too special to me.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment:
This is a very, very tense match of wits against the right opponent, with long considerations of which cards to play in battle (a cerebral Rock Paper Scissors challenge that I surprisingly like, considering how much I hate the RPS mechanics in many other games). Playing the Fellowship seems to be the easier of the two sides (at least in the classic game), which is a bit annoying but also provides a great "in" for teaching new people without trouncing them or throwing the game. I haven't even begun to scratch the surface of this edition, since we've yet to use the variant characters or the extra cards; I'm looking forward to how much replay value this little game will be able to provide!
P. S. I really like the production values on this Deluxe edition. Sure, everything is larger than it needs to be, leaving the box taking up "big box" game space on the shelf when the original was much smaller, but I love the larger-than-life cards and carved-looking character holders.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
Louis XIV
item.comment: Another game that I think is interesting but not necessarily -fun-. There's no denying that the mechanics are interesting and unique, but the game feels too fiddly; it's too easy to forget to flip royals or whether your pieces should go to the general supply or the personal supply. Neat area-majority feeling to the bribery but nothing feels quite intuitive enough to flow smoothly. Maybe with more plays these problems would go away as the game flow becomes second nature, but I'm not sure I'm willing to give it enough tries for that to happen.

item.name: Magdar
item.comment: Would probably be good with kids, but for real gamers, meh. Seems like you never get much done on your turn, there's very few options, winner often has 1 gem and a tiebreaker. Pass.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: Here's the quandary: I enjoy Magic a decent amount. But I don't enjoy the parts of it that come with it being a CCG--the giant metagame of building the tiniest, most efficient killing machine of a deck ("Aha, and I now cast an infinite-damage Fireball while simultaneously gaining infinite life!"), which depends on having decently large resources of time and money in order to do so properly. I think Magic is a fine game with some basic starter decks or a friendly draft from a common pool, but anything else is just getting too elitist and crappy for me.

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Manifest Destiny
item.comment: With the right group, this is amazing. But it is time-consuming and, in the end, war games (even when paired with really interesting decisions about technology and card management) just aren't my favorite way to spend time.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: Call of the Wild
Message to the Czar
item.comment: 4/16/10: After 1 5p play (with the official variant rules, which are all I would ever play with), I have to say I'm pretty happy with Message. For what it is--a light (by gamer standards) 30 minute filler--it's got enough interesting decisions to feel like it's more than just luck or chaos. Requires some forethought and tactical decision-making. There is a luck element with the coin-drawing that can be a bit rough if you're on the bad end of it, but for a short game that's not so frustrating. I'll hold onto this; it's hard to find a good filler game that isn't just a card game, and this feels unique.

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Metropolys has a neat bidding system that not only resolves who gets to place but -where-, meaning there' s a lot of strategy to working the bids around into the area where you want them. The hidden goals are okay, though some seem almost stupidly hard. I wish the colors of some areas were easier to distinguish but I appreciate that at least the building styles were different from color to color. Decent game, I'd play again, and if I were a bigger fan of area-control type games I'd probably love it, but as it is it's a good not great in my book.

item.name: Middle Kingdom
item.comment: One of those games I had never even heard of but just sort of fell into playing because I was asked to. After the rules were given, I almost considered bailing--it sounded dry as heck and just a bit muddled. But I stuck it out, and I'm glad I did! The bidding mechanic works very smoothly, and I love the tension that comes with hoping you don't tie with another player on your bid. The tie mechanic really makes the game, adding a lot more tactical consideration to bidding. The rest of the game is mostly set-collection, with a nice catch-up mechanic and some superpowers for being first in a group, and some weird scoring. I mostly won because other people playing didn't understand how powerful the farmers could be en masse. It was an interesting time and I'd definitely play again, though I'm not sure it's anything I'd ever buy.

item.name: Mille Bornes
item.comment: Mmph. Not a big fan of this one. Tended to degenerate into everyone drawing a card, saying "That's not what I needed," and discarding because they had a flat or whatever. Someone suggested it might work better if you could draw from the top of the discards, like gin rummy, and I'm inclined to agree, but I'm not sure I'm willing to play again to give that a shot.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: Probably the best two-player-only game I know. Very well thought-out and addictive. It's a brain-burner, and that's what I both love and hate about it. Like chess, it requires a fair amount of "If I go here, then my opponent will probably do this" predictions, and while satisfying as a logic puzzle, this can lead to long turn times with the wrong people. Might be good to use chess clocks if you're playing opponents who leave time for naps between moves. But the variety of characters and inherent randomness (Jack's identity, the witnesses who pop up on a given round, the Sherlock clues) give this a lot of replayability and make it an engaging diversion.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment:
An incredibly pleasant deduction game that requires more actual thought than, say, Clue. There are lots of interesting twists on the genre here--the frequent masses that require players to pass cards, in order to keep information flowing, the rules for asking and answering questions, the special library/scriptorium cards and mass-events--that keep the game feeling fresh.
And let's be blunt here: the penance system makes the game. When you tack on some extra rules for penance--not taking your turn in good time/not realizing it's your turn, swearing, answering ANY question falsely--it becomes a silly and fun party game in addition to a bit of a brain-burner.
