I suck at this game, no bones about it, but I still enjoy it and appreciate that it's possible to win without even guessing the correct suspect first, if you've made some smart revelations throughout the game. I wouldn't want to play it with less than 4 to 6, but it's a really nice medium group game that provokes a lot of laughs with the penance rules in effect.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: 4/23/10: Quick, lightweight wargame. Wargames aren't really my genre, but this is fast-paced and light enough that I enjoy it. The bits are incredibly eye-catching, and the exploration tiles and Secret Mission add nice incentives for being aggressive. Rather than having to drive your opponents extinct, you just need to get a certain amount of points from battles and associated gains, so the game doesn't drag on, and you are often encouraged to make non-optimal moves in order to fulfill missions. Nice to break out once in awhile.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: I got the opportunity to play it several times with my partner and in-laws over the holiday break, and we all seemed to enjoy it. There seemed to be several viable strategies to the game (I tried to take few cards and really push for chips when I could, while my mother-in-law took lots of cards and managed to chain them together in order to minimizes her losses and reap in tons of chips), and it was so simple to teach and play that non-gamers could easily be introduced to it. A good filler game that I can see coming out a lot.

item.name: On the Underground
item.comment: Okay, first, confession time: this got broken out as the "one last not-too-long game" at the end of a long game night, around 1:30am. Well, I was the one who added the "not too long" caveat and evidently my idea of not too long differs with those of others. I may have enjoyed this more when I wasn't tired and trying to get the house cleared up after game night. However, my complaints on it are pretty valid: lots of downtime, because this game is the capital of the country of Analysis Paralysis. You could spend HOURS min-maxing your rail placements for a turn, especially since the passenger movement is 100% predictable. I personally tried to make my turns 5 minutes or less, but it's one of those games that seems to just prompt you to spend waaay too long thinking about your turn, and no one else has anything to do during that time. Also, it can swing points somewhat unfairly if some players tend to get both gold and white cards out while others only get one color (I was on the lucky side of this phenomenon the time I played, but it still felt wrong). The mechanics are okay, I like the point-leeching you can accomplish by having a wide-spread rail system that the passenger will use a lot, but the game just ends up taking SO much longer than what it's worth.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: I'm not a big fan of improvisation, though I've gotten better over recent years. So I felt apprehensive when this got broken out over a New Years Eve dinner. But I gave it the ol' college try, and was surprised by how fun I found it. This is obviously one of those games that could be terrible with the wrong group, but the interrupting and stealing the story from someone so you could take it where you needed it to go worked well at keeping everyone involved. I think I need more practice, as I only had one chance at storytelling and found it too hard to interrupt people, but I think that would change with experience. A fun little party game.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: FINALLY have a copy of my own!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: Not quite sure of my opinion on this yet. Has some interesting Caylus-like mechanics paired with some nice randomness in turn order, but it just doesn't grab me like Caylus does. I feel like there should be more options in the randomness--a few playthroughs and you'll be more than familiar with most of the cards (I guess that's why there's an expansion). The board is beautiful, as many have said, and there's interesting parts but I just don't find it as intriguing as I think I should.

item.name: Pirate Dice: Voyage on the Rolling Seas
Polarity
item.comment:
When I first got Polarity and played it, I was a bit disappointed; it was not what I was expecting. I saw all the pictures on the 'Geek of carefully balanced magnets and thought that, however the scoring worked, the goal would be to be the player who could put on the best balancing act with your magnets.
Now that I've played a few times, I understand the game a bit better and it is growing on me as I shift my expectations. This is a game of carefully balancing playing-it-safe while attempting to force your opponent into a dumb or dangerous move, sort of akin to games like Jenga.
Bottom line, playing with the magnets is fun, and the rules are just an excuse to do so with some amount of structure and tension. Since all I've done so far is introduce people to the game and summarily trounce them since I have a better familiarity with the rules and a little more practice with the magnets, I can't say whether it's something I'd play over and over again with an equally-skilled partner. But it's a decent game, and like Fireball Island, is worth having simply for the fact that it attracts people to stand around and watch and be intrigued.

item.name: Police Precinct: Mad Men Deck Promo
Quarriors! Quarmageddon Multiplying Mischievous Imp Promo Card
Quoridor
item.comment: Pretty game, and interesting enough for its incredibly short length. I prefer 4-player, as it's a little more unpredictable and the moves seem a little less obvious (though there is large kingmaker potential), but it's fun enough either way, and 2p it's only like 5 minutes, so.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
I waver on race. It's a really decent resource-machine-building game, but there are some niggling problems with it that keep it from being any sort of sworn-by-favorite for me.
First and foremost--and I'm aware of the few vehement fans who will chomp at the bit regarding this statement--there is not much interaction in RftG. Let's go ahead and compare it to San Juan, since such a comparison is inevitable; the role-drafting in SJ gives enough interaction that I can't effectively play the whole game with my eyes solely on my own cards. With RftG, I can certainly benefit from looking at my competitors' setups, both to attempt to mind-read what phase they will play and also to know what cards to keep from them. But in the end, I can do a decent job solely from staring at my own setup--in my group, I generally do just this, since the game goes by too quickly for me to pick up everyone's cards and examine them to understand what they're doing.
Which leads to the second and third problems: the vast variety of cards that are too hard to distinguish for a casual player, and the iconography. The latter is actually sort of enjoyable for me, but poses such a large learning barrier for new players that it makes RftG much less of a game I'd introduce to people than San Juan, where all the cards say clearly what they do. The former is a particular problem for me; I've played RftG over a dozen times, but only know what a handful of worlds and buildings do by name. San Juan only has a couple dozen buildings, and I could tell you what most of them do off the top of my head, and I've only played SJ one more time than RftG. This makes it so other players can't just announce "I built New Epsilon" and I will immediately know what they're doing. Supposedly the iconography should help with this, but I find that realistically, it's too much trouble to figure out what my opponents are doing except in a two player game.
All that said, RftG is enjoyable. I particularly think it's a good, 15-20 minute 2-player game, since you have more control over phases in this game and can pay more attention to your opponent. I think if I played RftG several dozen times and was intimately familiar with all the cards, I'd find it's a much more interactive game, but I find that necessary time-investment a bit of a minus. I'm hoping that the Gathering Storm expansion, with its ability to aggress on opponents, will help with this problem without making the military strategy too powerful. We'll see.
In the end, RftG is a decent game, but I prefer San Juan and since I own the latter, I don't have a great drive to get Race.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: I personally find the Rare Element-brown and the Gene Element-green quite hard to distinguish, especially their windfalls.
ADDITIONAL NOTE ADDED AFTER ORIGINAL COMMENT: Oh god why can't I stop playing?

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
item.wishlistcomment: Is more like a 1-2 but don't have any constant always-willing opponents like I did in Athens (yet).

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Brink of War
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment:
This is a great expansion to Race. While there aren't many cards in it, those that are make for some new, interesting strategies. Furthermore, the inclusion of Improved Logistics (which allows one to settle twice in a single settle phase) means you have to be even more aware of what your opponent is doing, to make sure you're prepared in case they end the game earlier than you expected. The new Start Worlds are great--it's so nice to not see the same old first five anymore, and they all feel pretty much on par, strength-wise, with the originals while maintaining their own feel. The goals are probably the most important part of the expansion, to me. While I know some despise them, I think they're fantastic; they have caused me to pay so much more attention to what my opponent(s) is/are doing and give me some direction with my opening plays when my cards don't seem to have a coherent strategy.
The solitaire game is alright. I think they did a nice job making an interesting robot mechanic, but it's just not what I personally look for in a solitaire game. (I tend to go to adventure-type or coop games for solitaire play.) I can't comment on the 5th player addition, since I personally find 4 to be pretty overwhelming with RftG as it is and am not in a terrible rush to try another person on top of that.

item.name: Rage
item.conditiontext: Good condition, played once, some box wear.

item.name: Red November
item.comment:
Another "heard about from Essen" must-have, though it didn't come nearly as strongly recommended as Ghost Stories. I traded away my copy of A Touch of Evil Supernatural Game for enough cash to buy this and No Thanks!, since I was finding more and more that AToE was just not really my speed. After two plays with mostly-new crowds, I'm pretty fond of this little game. The tiny board and pieces do make it feel a bit cramped (though I appreciate the small box!), but it's a fun, chaotic mess of a co-op. It's got some flaws, particularly that a few players felt that there was too much downtime between turns (I personally invest myself in everyone's turns and try to group-problem-solve so I didn't feel this as much) and some rules clarifications that are thankfully on the BGG forums, but for a cheap and small game, I think it's a good buy. Another co-op that avoids the "alpha player" problem by having so much going wrong that there isn't a single right answer; you just have to cross your fingers and dive into a problem and hope you chose the right one.
Updated comments:
Bleh. Got old fast.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: I am a bit horrified but also curious.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Late Bronze Age
Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment: I was disappointed in Runebound; it sounded totally my speed. But it ended up being a fairly bland "wander around and kill stuff for a few hours" experience. Maybe with PvP the game would go better and be more interactive (I worry it would also take even longer, though maybe it would just help the strongest player win sooner), but as it was, it was clear who the winner was an hour before we finished. Granted, we were playing with five people--I hear this is too many for the game to really be of a desirable length--but even that aside, I found the flavor to be lacking (distinguishing it from better "wander around and do stuff" games like Arkham), the mechanics to be nothing special (except for a kind of cool movement system), and it spent far too long in the middle stages of 2nd and 3rd level adventures before we were ready to take on the big bads at the end.

item.name: Runebound: Artifacts and Allies
item.comment: I only played Runebound once and this and Drakes and Dragonspawn were mixed in, so I don't know how different they made it from the base, since I never played the base by myself. I will say, however, that we were DROWNING in allies in our game, and had difficulty finding actual equipment because of this; I suspect this expansion is somewhat to blame.

item.name: Runebound: Drakes and Dragonspawn
item.comment: Only played Runebound once, with this mixed in, so I really don't know how different from the base game it makes things. The end dragons seemed interesting, though, and I have to guess that at least some were from this expansion.

item.name: Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion
item.comment: I enjoy St. Pete's, but I've found after several plays that it has started to feel a bit dry and predictable. This expansion was just what the game needed. I can see the upsetness some people have over it--it makes St. Pete's into a bit more of a crazy, unpredictable beast and less a tight, strategic economy game. But that's okay--I like crazy and unpredictable. I will say that the Banquet cards seemed a little less useful than they should've been (except the one that doubled a card's output, and the double-turn card), but were ok. The new buildings, workers, nobles, and upgrades, and updated Mistresses and Observatories were really where it was at, though. I was getting a bit bored of St. Pete's, but I would definitely play it again with the expansion.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: While I am tired of the plantation-worker theme, Santiago adds enough to the formula to keep it fresh. The tactical choices in whether to be the irrigation manager, how much to bid for your choice irrigation spot, etc. adds a lot of interaction and diplomacy to what could've been a very dry (excuse the pun) and generic cube-pushing experience. The point multipliers you can earn by grouping like vegetables--even with your opponents--make the game even more interesting, as there's constant debate over whether it's worth giving your opponent more points in order to jump in on their huge patch of peppers. Great game, I'm looking forward to trying this again.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: Not an awful game, but I feel that it's really too long for what it is. The theme feels tacked-on (I know that some would strongly disagree with me on this), and it just boils down to an (to me) annoying exercise in number-crunching. And that's coming from a statistician. I prefer its "diet" version, Phoenicia (or Phoenicia's more flashy cousin, Vegas Showdown); they have the same draw for me but don't take nearly as long.

item.name: Scripts and Scribes: The Dice Game
Seismic
item.comment: Picked up for $2 at a thrift store in near-new condition. I wasn't expecting anything earth-shattering (see what I did there?), and it was cheap, so I'm satisfied with it. If I'd paid MSRP I'm sure I'd feel entirely ripped off, however. This Carc-with-earthquakes game is mildly fun, mostly due to the tension involved in waiting for an earthquake to screw everything up, but the fact that there's only one way to score (completing loops, as compared to the numerous ways in Carc) and the bits and tiles are a bit boring, art-wise, means that this probably won't hit the table too often.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: G.I. Bunker Promo Card
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Infernal Relics
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Mad Bomber Blade Villain Promo Card
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City – The Wraith Promo Card
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Shattered Timelines
Sentinels of the Multiverse: The Super Scientific Tachyon Promo Card
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Unity Hero Character
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Young Legacy Promo Card
SET
item.comment:
I've played this once or twice, but will not rate it because I can't do so fairly: I'm red-green colorblind and have too much trouble telling color-sets apart to be competitive. So, consider that a word of warning on this game (though I've heard there's a color-blind variant?).
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: This is totally redundant with what I just wrote, but I want to be super-clear about it: NOT RED-GREEN CB FRIENDLY. When the shapes are totally filled in, I can distinguish them, but when they're just outlined or patterned, I find it nigh-impossible to tell them apart quickly, and you NEED to be able to do so in a split-second to be competitive. WHYYYYY can't they make games like this in, say, red/blue/black instead of red/green/blue? Or red/blue/yellow? Why choose the MOST COMMON TWO COLORS FOR COLORBLINDNESS to include? ARGH!

item.name: The Settlers of the Stone Age
Shadow Hunters
item.comment: This is a game that takes the fun parts of Bang! and does them correctly. The Hermit cards allow you to identify who is on your term before you accidentally shoot them to death, and the game only lasts a good 20-30 minutes. Plus, there's a lot less of the "I shoot you!," "Ha, you missed!" trade-off. The board is simple but thematically appropriate and attractive, and there's, of course, the sick joy that comes from attacking an enemy with a machine gun and a chainsaw and a cursed sword all at once. This is a fun filler of a hidden-teams, kill-everyone sort of game, and I can definitely see it being broken out a decent amount for groups of 6+.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment:
Merlin's Company is a fantastic expansion for Shadows over Camelot. It adds just enough spice to make the game feel very new and exciting, while not messing with the balance of the original too much. Some people were disappointed that there were no new quests in it; I, personally, feel that this was the correct decision for the designers to make. Another quest would have spread the already-thin knights' resources too much. Instead, the Travel deck adds an entirely new mechanic that makes decisions about switching quests or returning to Camelot more difficult, but has enough positive notes to it (Merlin coming on the Grail quest, for example, can be completely invaluable) to keep the game from being too easy to lose (or win if you're the traitor). Many of the new characters are interesting and fun to play. I'm delighted to finally have a die and real sheet for Sir Bedivere. And the new White/Black cards are gruesomely overpowered in that wonderful way only expansions deliver (see also Last Night On Earth: Growing Hunger). Oh, and being able to have 2 traitors in large-group games makes it extra exciting.
Unfortunately, soon after I got this, Battlestar Galactica came along soon afterward and blew me away, and I'm not sure how often SoC will hit the table anymore. :(

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Sir Bedivere, the 8th Knight
Shogun
item.comment: As far as I'm concerned, this is "Cube Tower: The Game." I didn't care about much else in the experience; it's a fairly straightforward resource-gathering meets Risk experience. Not to say that it's not good, I think there's a lot of strategy in this and a good mix of randomness with hidden information, bluffing, and careful forethought. But it, overall, wasn't my cup of tea; I frankly suck at Risk and all games like it, and I don't have much of an investment in feudal Japan, so the theme didn't do anything for me. But the cube tower is quite possibly one of the coolest game gimmicks ever. We were having huge battles just for the pure joy of dumping giant numbers of cubes in that thing and watching what happened. I would probably play this again, just to play with the tower. So, well done to whoever though that one up.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Enjoyed this more than I thought I would. Felt a lot less wargamey than it looks. Not really investing in your race for more than a couple turns helps conflicts feel a lot less personal. Looks complicated, but felt pretty simple to get into, and not too much brain-burning. Interested in trying with a full five.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
Space Alert
item.comment: One of the most innovative games I've played in a long time. Making a real-time co-op solves all the complains of "solved" games where an alpha player can control it by themself; there is far too much chaos and uncertainty here for one person to possibly direct all the other crew members exactly. Everyone needs to be on the ball and engaging; the table is filled with screaming, pointing fingers, and confusion (at least until communications go down :devil: ). The resolution phase is met with groans of dawning comprehension, laughter, and (hopefully) cheers and hi-fives. A game this exciting and emotionally engaging deserves a 10, particularly when it only takes a half hour. The only qualm is getting a regular group together to play; otherwise, you'll be running a lot of training missions for the benefit of newbies.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game – Mission Pack 1
Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game: Space Marine Pack 1
StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: Not bad for what it is. I am awful at this sort of game, so it's hard for me to comment; I end up trying to turtle and just mind my own business and getting summarily slaughtered (especially since my opponent was playing the Zerg). But it had some interesting elements and I'd give it a few more goes (hopefully with more than 2 people), because it was interesting even if I'll never win at it.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Phoenix Elves vs Tundra Orcs
item.conditiontext: Missing one of the twenty wound markers but in otherwise great condition.

item.name: Super Scrabble
item.comment: A stunning example in how to take a fantastic classic game and ruin it. Super Scrabble attempts to "improve" Scrabble by, basically, inflating scores (by adding quadruple-scoring opportunities) and making it bigger (bigger board and DOUBLE the number of letter tiles). The latter is particularly an awful idea; this makes what was a good game into an exercise in tedium, as Super Scrabble lasts FOREVER. The original could tend to go long due to AP problems; doubling its length, effectively, destroys the enjoyability of the game. The only purpose I can see in Super Scrabble is for bragging rights about that time you scored 800 points, but you'd be better off just doubling your score from a regular Scrabble game and pretending that was your score; you'll save a lot of time.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! 5-6 Player Mini Expansion
Survive: Escape from Atlantis! The Giant Squid Mini Expansion
Taluva
item.comment: Came in expecting to really enjoy this, but just was left feeling a bit empty. The lack of congruency in landscape leaves it looking much more jumbled and ugly than Carcassonne, and the victory conditions just didn't feel all that interesting to me. Easy to overthink. I liked the neat vertical building but just overall felt unimpressed.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: 9/27/08: Of note. In a four-player game, Kiyomi got 448 points. FOUR HUNDRED FORTY EIGHT. Next highest score was just under four hundred; myself and the third place player had around two hundred. ...my mind, she is blown.

item.name: Thunderstone: Wrath of the Elements
item.comment: Rating is admittedly only based on one play. But from what I saw, this expansion tries [b]far too hard[/b] to turn things up to 11, and ends up with a bunch of cards that have lots of extra little fiddlies on 'em and makes an already slightly-too-long game even more tedious. The only thing that kept this at a 5 instead of below is the fact that they used this expansion to apologize for and improve upon the horrendous storage scheme for the base game.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Played this a bit after a game of Ticket to Ride, and it's easy to see the comparisons between the two. There was some neat stuff going on in Thurn--the tension of deciding whether to continue your route another turn or cash it in right away, for example--but it just didn't click very well for me. The scoring and objectives just seemed a bit obscure and I just had a harder time being able to do the things I wanted to than I do in TtR. Again, hard to find things to say. It just didn't sit as well with me as TtR; the extra bookkeeping involved didn't seem worth the trade-off.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis: Power and Glory
Ticket to Ride: Märklin
item.comment: Seems like the passengers are a totally unnecessary addition to the game.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
item.comment: This was kind of a pleasant surprise! I'll be honest and say that I think the original TtR games are enjoyable enough but not the be-all and end-all that they seem to be among some Geeks. But I figured I'd give this one a shot during a long game day yesterday--especially since the designers continued to be thoughtful in using symbols along with colors for us color-impaired folk--and I think I may have enjoyed it more than the TtR board games I've played. It's substantially different--it barely even feels like the same game--but that's not necessarily a bad thing. TtR:tCG is a tense memory battle with a bit of screw-your-neighbor by canceling out their groups of colors. There's a nice feeling that you could have done better at the end, when you see that you have a couple wilds you didn't need in your deck and realize you could've easily taken another ticket or two. I'll play TtR when other people want to, but I may actually suggest trying TtR:tCG again myself; it's shorter and more enjoyable than its board game sibling, for me.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: 5/8/10: 1st play. Wow! For a set of relatively simple rules (there are a few too many fiddly exceptions to make them just "simple"), this game seems awfully dynamic. There's a [b]lot[/b] going on in this 1-1.5 hour slugfest. I already see layers upon layers going on here, and unlike a game like Chess or Go, I don't feel like it's totally impenetrable. This is staying in my collection for quite awhile, I think.

item.name: Timbuktu
item.comment: An ok deduction-based game. I like that the deductions aren't the victory condition in themselves, but rather a means to an end (getting your stuff to the end safely). You don't get all the info for any round, and so have to make some educated guesses, and you can get lucky or unlucky early in a round, which adds some tension and groan-worthy moments when you realize later in the round that you just set yourself up to get totally robbed blind by the raiders. We played a shortened 5-player game (four rounds instead of five), and I'm grateful in that I think it was starting to wear a bit old by that time. It's not a bad game, but it started to get a bit repetitive. Still, it's nice to have a deduction game that the winner isn't just the first person to declare it was Father Bruno in the Lobby with the Cube Tower or whatever, but rather who can put that info to the best use.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: Brain-burner! Not necessarily in a bad way, though. Be very careful who to play with, could be a terrible min/max AP clusterbomb. Need multiplicative scoring scheme, and the action cards add just enough extra spice to it to keep it from feeling completely dry.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment:
A fairly light (in terms of mood, not mechanics; the rules are a bit fiddly the first couple times) competitive game that feels like a cross between Talisman/Runebound and Cutthroat Caverns, with flavor text and a mechanic or two stolen from Arkham and pretty much all its style and layout lifted straight from Last Night on Earth. Nothing earth-moving, but a fun race to kill the monster sort of game.
Co-op does not work very well; it lacks the tenseness needed to really make for a good challenge, even with the Epic Showdown chart.
Surprisingly enough, though, the game actually works quite well solo, with a single investigator. When the Mystery phase is every round, there's enough bite from the game to make it a close call. Plus you can play it in about a half hour solo!
item.conditiontext: Semi-useless insert tossed; bits bagged and figurines are in a small box to keep them from being crushed. Played a few times but everything in great shape! Printouts of the Dryad Villain from the website included (on regular printed paper).

item.name: Tribune: Primus Inter Pares
item.comment: Another game I expected to like more than I did. Now, I played it 3-player and have heard that this is not the optimal number of players, but even still I found the game to be a bit lackluster. It was a PRETTY game, with FFG's hilarious penchant for overproduction in strange places, but the actual gameplay felt both overwhelming and undersatisfying. I'm going to give this another try or two before I definitively say whether I think it's overrated or not, since I feel that part of my problem was just a general lack of direction and understanding of the win conditions, but I just didn't feel terribly satisfied with the game, even though I liked some of its aspects.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar – Tribes & Prophecies
Undercut
item.comment: To be honest, this is probably the first Icehouse game I've played that really feels totally unique in a good way (other than Zendo, but I also feel like Zendo could just be played with about anything). I have never played anything quite like Undercut. It's an auctioning game where you actively do NOT want to win what's up for auction. Rather, the auction is an opportunity to get RID of what you have. You want to avoid making sets of your pieces, and every turn you are forced to bid in auctions on more pieces, meaning that you'll have a harder and harder time not making sets. So you attempt to figure out how you can bid and win auctions with the pieces you want to get rid of so that the pieces you acquire don't make you have a set. Neat neat neat mechanics, I'm really impressed with the ingenuity that went into this. That said, it seemed to drag on a good bit past its welcome (at least with our five-player game). It should be about a 30 minute game, enjoyment-wise, but went on for right about an hour. I think familiarity would make it go a bit quicker, but I still think that as it is, it goes on for a bit too long. Part of the problem is that the system of using the pieces you want to get rid of as currency has the effect that people make some ludicrously large bids at first just to see if they can get away with it, and the slow paring down of bids to a reasonable size takes several turns. Still, all said, I thought Undercut was interesting, to say the least. It's nothing I'd beg to play again, but if asked I'd probably be up for a second go-round.

item.name: Uptown
item.comment: When this got broken out, I was a little unsure. First, it looks pretty plain, and while we all know that looks aren't anything, it can be hard to get excited about a game you know nothing about when there's no flashy FFG art or anything on it. Plus, the board struck me immediately as very like that of Acquire, which is a good game, but one I am awful at. But we gave it a try with our group of four, and I actually found it a pretty enjoyable brain-burner of a game. I'd like to try it again with five, since I feel like the game could only be better with more jostling. What makes Uptown is its tie-breaker system. See, the goal is to get as few contiguous groups of tiles in your color as possible (i.e. ideally, all your tiles should be in one big group). To accomplish this, you may bump other player's tiles off the board with your own (under certain conditions). But at the end of the game, ties are broken by who has done so the LEAST. So you have to ask yourself whether it's worth it, or, even better, try to force your opponents to eat your tiles. I ignored this aspect at first--I'm used to shoving "tiebreaker rules" into the back of the mind, since they're rarely used--but ties are frequent in this game, and this part ultimately makes the game work as well as it does. I'd definitely give this another shot, especially with five people, because it was a fun time. It's nothing I'd ever own, though, I think.

item.name: Virus Fight
item.comment: An interesting little game for Treehouse pieces, but it didn't click to well with me. Maybe if I played often enough that I didn't have to consult the list of what color does what, it would be more fun and drag less, but I'm not sure I'm willing to put that sort of time into it. It's an interesting little thing to try once, basically.

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment: After seeing all the Essen buzz about this new Zman game, I was excited to try a friend's newly acquired copy. I guess the hype hurt this one for me; I was left asking "THIS is what BGG is so abuzz about?" Now, there's nothing wrong with Wasabi. It's a cute little tile-placement game with some good opportunities for messing around with your opponents and trying to convert your opponent's moves into things that work for you. But I was left feeling that a lot of whether my recipes got made or not was due to luck--if my opponents happened to make a similar recipe or accidentally place two pieces together I needed. Maybe after more plays, I'd get better at the game and be able to better recognize what others are doing and how to use it to my advantage. But it just left me feeling a bit unsatisfied, like an appetizer with no main course to follow. Not a bad game by any means, I'm just a bit stumped as to how it got SO MUCH buzz on the Geek. (Though I admit to being in love with the little bowls and wasabi cubes.)

item.name: Wicked Witches Way
item.conditiontext: Edition/Language: "Wicked Witches Way" (pictured) edition, Asmodee, English. Condition: Only played a couple times, in very good condition. Except 2 of the "Tailwind" black magic card are missing--I received this in a trade, trusted it was complete, and just found out now. (Please double-check your stuff before you send it, people :soblue: )

item.name: Zendo
item.comment: I'd seen this game around on the BGG forums, so had a pretty good grasp of how it worked already (though I'd never heard the whole "Mondo" part). It's a quick and enjoyable little group puzzle-solving game. A cute and fun way to pass a few minutes. Can be endlessly frustrating if the Master makes obscure or confusing rules, however. Like teachers, I think there's a definite type of person who makes a good Master, and others who kind of muddle through.

item.name: Zing!
item.comment:
I have the more bright-and-flashy Zing!, and have to say that just looking at pictures on BGG, die Sieben Siegel looks cooler. But, that aside, this is actually a pretty decent little trick-taking game. It requires an amazing accuracy in bidding that will take a lot of practice to perfect, I think, but that's not a complaint; I just think I'll have a better feel for the game after a few more plays. There are some really interesting mechanics at play here that makes it a very fun screwing-everyone-and-defending-yourself trick-taking game. Plus there's what amounts to an overt Traitor role every round, a single player dedicated to messing everyone else up. I doubt I'll play it often with four--our group is a dedicated set of Tichu fanatics--but with five I would definitely break this out from time to time.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: The cards are pretty distinguishable, since they have slight 'texture' differences in how the backlighting and swooshes across the card art from color to color. However, I found that making out what trick markers other players had in front of them, particularly across the table, was sometimes difficult.

item.name: Zoff in Buffalo
item.comment:
Zoff in Buffalo is one of those games where you are partway through your first game when, suddenly, you realize that what you took as a largely chance-based game turns out to be terribly tactical--it's just that the tactics are about something completely different from what you thought the game is about. The game just plugs along until a suddenly very tense end-game of placement. There were some interesting placement rules here that kept it feeling unique, and the endgame was fun even though my color-blindness allowed some stupid errors on my end to slip through when I didn't realize some blue and purple bits were different colors. Oh, well. I'd give this another shot now that I understand it a bit better.
COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: I personally found the blue and purple pieces very hard to distinguish, leading to some stupid plays on my part. Careful!

item.name: Zombie State: Diplomacy of the Dead
